title: 108_hr1349
content: The Act titled "National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program Improvement Act of 2003" amends the basis for calculating projected lost earnings under the Public Health Service Act. It now includes the average gross weekly earnings of full-time workers aged 18 and over in the private nonfarm sector, minus taxes and health insurance costs. The National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program Improvement Act of 2003 increases the award for vaccine-related deaths from $250,000 to $300,000. It also allows compensation for family counseling expenses and expenses of establishing guardianship. The National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program Improvement Act of 2003 increases the award for vaccine-related deaths and allows compensation for family counseling expenses and expenses of establishing guardianship. The Act includes provisions for actual nonreimbursable expenses incurred for family counseling and expenses to establish and maintain a guardianship for individuals with vaccine-related injuries. The National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program Improvement Act of 2003 allows compensation for family counseling expenses and expenses of establishing and maintaining guardianships for individuals with vaccine-related injuries. SEC. 5. Allowing payment of interim attorneys' fees and costs. Section 2115(e) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow special masters to make interim awards of attorneys' fees and costs in vaccine injury cases meeting certain criteria. The special master can make interim awards of attorneys' fees and costs in vaccine injury cases. The Secretary must promptly pay the interim award without needing a judgment. The final attorneys' fees and costs awarded as compensation will be for the total incurred in the proceeding, minus the interim amount. The special master can reconsider and modify fees and costs awarded in vaccine injury cases. The special master can reconsider and modify attorneys' fees in vaccine injury cases. Section 2115(e) of the Public Health Service Act allows for attorneys' fees and costs to be payable solely to the petitioner's attorney under certain circumstances. Attorneys' fees and costs can be paid solely to the petitioner's attorney under specific circumstances, such as when there is no practical alternative means for reimbursement or in exceptional circumstances with good cause. SEC. 7. EXTENSION OF STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS. Section 2116(a) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to extend the limitation period for filing a petition related to vaccine injuries or deaths. The amendment changes the time period from months to 6 years for certain cases. The limitation period for filing a petition related to vaccine injuries or deaths is extended to the later of the applicable date under section 2116(a) of the Public Health Service Act or 2 years after the enactment of this Act. A petition filed within this period may not be dismissed for untimely filing. Additionally, claims based on revisions to the table must meet certain conditions to file a petition for compensation. The extension allows for filing petitions related to vaccine injuries or deaths within specific timeframes. The petition must meet conditions for compensation, including timelines for occurrence of symptoms and filing. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to submit annual reports to Congress on filed petitions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must provide reports to Congress on the effects of subsection (b) on the administration of the National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program and the timely adjudication of petitions. The first report is due within 1 year of the Act's enactment, and the second report within 2 years. SEC. 8. ADVISORY COMMISSION ON CHILDHOOD VACCINES. Amends the selection criteria for public members to include individuals affected by vaccine-related injuries or deaths. Eliminates the mandatory meeting schedule. SEC. 9. CONFORMING AMENDMENT TO TRUST FUND PROVISION. SEC. 9 amends the Internal Revenue Code for vaccine-related injury or death. SEC. 10 increases the limit on administrative expenses. SEC. 10 increases the limit on administrative expenses to $10,000,000 for any fiscal year. It also includes the payment of administrative and personnel expenses for financial services for the Trust Fund. SEC. 11 amends the Public Health Service Act to include a public service announcement campaign. SEC. 12 states that certain provisions and amendments apply to petitions filed under the Act.
